description: From a Middle English rebracketing of a noumpere as an oumpere, from Old French nonper (“odd number, not even (as a tie-breaking arbitrator)”), from non (“not”) + per (“equal”), from Latin par (“equal”).

entries.meaning: (tennis, badminton) The official who presides over a tennis match sat on a high chair.
(cricket) One of the two white-coated officials who preside over a cricket match.
(baseball) One of the officials who preside over a baseball game.
examples: The umpire called the pitch a strike.

entries.meaning: (American football) The official who stands behind the line on the defensive side or next to the referee on the offensive side.
examples: The umpire must keep on his toes as the play often occurs around him.

entries.meaning: (Australian rules football) A match official on the ground deciding and enforcing the rules during play. As of 2007 the Australian Football League uses three; in the past there were two or just one. The other officials, the goal umpires and boundary umpires, are usually referred to by those phrases.
(law) A person who arbitrates between contending parties.
(curling) The official who presides over a curling game.

verbs.description: umpire (third-person singular simple present umpires, present participle umpiring, simple past and past participle umpired)

entries.meaning: (sports, intransitive) To act as an umpire in a game.
